replies.body: Soooo him blocking a Blitz Q is stupid or am I missing the point here

I think the point of that particular video was that Yasuo managed to block a projectile on a direct path to him by firing his Wind Wall in what was ostensibly the wrong direction. The implication is therefore that Yasuo, despite being advertized as a skill-intensive champion, can get out of some pretty heavy situations without demonstrating really all that much skill. This isn't an assessment I personally agree completely with, though I do think that there are some under-the-hood mechanics in Yasuo's kit that lean pretty generously in his favor, such as Wind Wall's hitbox that affords less directional precision on his part.
I mean: Same can Fiora w do regardless the direction you use it if i remember correctly.
fioras W is a different mechanic, she stands still while casting it, yasuo can move freely when casting his W

On the other side Fiora takes 0 non turret damage while yasuo is still vulnerable to lasers. i don't realy know why people coplain here for not geting grabed if most champs could have dodged it with a dash (fiora q wih moving for example), if amde good even after geting grabed by blitz (tristana w), other invulnerable abilitys (xayah ult, fizz e, vlad w, kled dismount) would do the same.

Fiora W is because she ccs herself. Her Q goes on longer CD if she doesn't hit anything, so she's punished for missing Q a lot more than other champs because of how bread-and-butter it is to her kit (vs say Yas E).

Xayah gets away because it's an ult (same with Eve or Ekko or I guess Bard too)

Fizz's "troll pole" has been complained about a ton. The only reason ppl stop is because the rest of his kit/numbers have been pretty heavily gimped and Riot created a new target for people to focus on with his reliance on landing R

Vlad pool leads to a long period of him not being able to do dmg (he can charge E) that, while offering a longer period of invulnerability than the other types, also makes him not do dmg for the same time. The rest of the kit really has no defensive tools either, so it's seen as more "fair," compared to Fizz/Yas/Fiora/Ekko's high mobility, Eve's stealth, or Bard's Q/E chain. Ok the pool does actually do dmg, but it's easily avoidable and isn't very high. Main point being, the rest of his kit justifies the invulnerability, so his pool is generally perceived as a fair trade-off for a balanced kit.

Kled dismount was also complained a lot about during release. A lot of people still find it annoying, but Kled doesn't really have that much choice in when it procs, and it should rarely be happening. His lack of agency in determining the invulnerability helps with the fair aspect.

Other sources of invulnerability:

Maokai's W: no idea why people don't complain about that one. It can dodge a lot of dmg and it's on a relatively low cd. I guess it's because he doesn't do enough immediate dmg (he can do a lot in lane) to the degree that people will complain about. Maybe since invulnerability helps him live longer, it's seen as a tool to help make him "tankier"? 

Aatrox passive: similar to kled passive. Also counterbalanced by how horrible the rest of his kit is

Camille/Kalista/Illaoi/Galio/Pantheon/Xin Zhao/kayle/Kayn/Liss/Rek'sai/Taric R: It's an ultimate

Elise: conditional enough that people don't complain about it that much. They do complain how much it helps her dive, but she's supposed to be a diver.

Master Yi: If people complain about him it's his dmg and high ms. If anything his Q is seen as somewhat inhibitionary because it lowers his DPS, gives time for abilities to go off CD, and because of the "I was in alpha" meme

Karthus: Needs to be dead. And it's part of his identity.

The way it is expected to function (based on the fact that he casts it in a direction and based on the visuals for it) is directional. But it works in more ways than just directional. I understand that timing is still a factor, but I find it somewhat misrepresented if casting it as a reaction like this Yasuo in the video did - and in doing so, aiming it poorly - still rewards him with the safety that would be expected from aiming it correctly.

"If you mean making mistakes and being rewarded then you have more than just Yasuo doing that"

I mean precisely this. And other champions having a similar problem is no excuse to leave Yasuo with the same problem. You're engaging in 'whataboutism' saying, yeah it's wrong, but what about all those other people who are also wrong?

That isn't relevant to this discussion. If you want to make a post about how LOTS of champions are rewarded for their mistakes, go right ahead! But please, let's not derail the conversation here with that topic.

> Now I won't go off and say "FUCK YOU DUMBASS" because I'm not a jerk, but 

Well, I mean... you kind of did say it. But okay. I understand you are frustrated, and I'm not going to take it personally or get offended.

> Do you know how much time Yasuo Mains put into the guy to even be good at him? I barely get an S at all now, thanks to his neRFz. I wouldn't even say I'm that good at Yasuo, yet I spent such a huge amount of time into him. I honestly SHOULD have a rewarding experience playing the champion I had to master to get that experience. The entire problem with Yasuo is that he is toxic and no one knows how to fight him. Why? Mainly because they ban him and not learn how to counter him. No one realizes that he's hot garbage even though you can show them the statistics in their face.

I don't dispute that he takes skill to play. He certainly does. What I'm opposed to is how his mechanics place an unusually large burden of knowledge and skill on both his player and his opponents when trying to play as and against him. The problem isn't the high burden itself, the problem is that a Yasuo main and his opponent do not have the same opportunity to develop those skills and knowledge.

The Yasuo main has lots and lots of game-time to practice Yasuo and work out all the kinks in their techniques when playing him. While the player playing against him only sees a Yasuo once every 15 to 20 games that they play. See how they might not have an equal opportunity to develop their skills against him?

_(Fun fact: this is also why Yasuo struggles so much at higher levels of play and stomps at lower levels. It's because he has a lot of little things that can be taken advantage of (both as and against him) if you know about them, and at higher levels of play the opponents are more likely to have had the time put into figuring out all of the complex counterplay. And once people know his counterplay he becomes significantly weaker.)_

**I'm not arguing for Yasuo to simply be nerfed.** I want the complex things in his kit to be toned down so that more of his power budget is freed up to make changes that reduce the burden on both Yasuo and his opponents when playing as or against him. I want him to be buffable so that he can be made stronger without breaking the game, and I want him to be made **less** complex to play against so that opponents do not feel overwhelmed by the burden of dealing with his mechanics.

> There is no real way to fix Yasuo's W. You can say "its strong" and "its hard to get past" and all that, but his W and his passive (the shield one, you know, with the shield that can block 550 damage but still get taken down by 1 single point of any type of damage) are the only things that keep him from being unplayable. You can't figure out how to not make Yasuo garbage while at the same time nerfing W, and it seems like RIOT can't either.

Indeed there is a significant problem with Wind Wall. I do not think it is impossible to fix, but I do recognize that it is a significantly complex problem and the act of making changes to address it would affect a very large and passionate portion of the player-base.

This is why I like having discussions such as this, where we analyze what the problems might be and discuss possible ways to fix them without just fucking over the champion and his playerbase. The more we discuss it the more likely we are to find a great solution!
